speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these episodes of dizziness and vertigo started happening? Was it sudden or did they come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "I started noticing these episodes about 6 months ago, and they seem to come out of the blue. One minute I'm standing still, and the next, I feel like I'm spinning around. It's hard to describe, but it's like the room is moving around me, even when I'm not moving."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the episodes? Do they seem to be triggered by anything, such as stress, certain activities, or changes in your environment?

speaker: Patient
text: "They don't seem to be triggered by anything, at least that's what I've noticed. Sometimes I'll be watching TV or reading a book, and then suddenly I'll feel this sensation, but other times it just happens out of the blue, like I said. It's like my inner ear is playing tricks on me."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities? Are you able to perform tasks that require balance, such as walking or cooking, without assistance?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, I've been managing to do most things on my own, but I do have to be more careful now. I'll be walking down the hallway, and suddenly I'll feel a bit off balance, so I'll grab onto the wall to steady myself. It's nothing too severe, but it's definitely made me more cautious about my movements."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities? Do you have any jobs or hobbies that require you to be on your feet for long periods of time? Also, have you noticed any other symptoms besides the dizziness and vertigo, such as ringing in your ears or hearing loss?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I used to be a school teacher, so I'm used to being on my feet for long periods of time. But now that I'm retired, I don't have as much opportunity to be active. As for other symptoms, I do have some hearing loss, but it's just the usual presbycusis that comes with getting older. I can still hear just fine, it's just that my hearing isn't as sharp as it used to be."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your hearing loss? Is it a gradual decline or did it start suddenly as well? Also, I'd like to perform a physical examination to assess your balance and vestibular function. Can you stand up for me and hold onto the table for support?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'd say it's a gradual decline, but it's getting a bit worse over time. I can still carry on conversations, but I have to ask people to speak up and repeat what they said. It's not severe, but it's definitely noticeable, especially in noisy environments. I've just gotten used to it, you know?" "I'd be happy to stand up for you and hold onto the table for support. I've been doing that a lot lately, actually, to make sure I don't trip or stumble. It's just become a part of my daily routine, I suppose."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for standing up for me. I'd like to perform a Romberg test to assess your balance. Can you stand here with your feet shoulder-width apart, hold onto the table for support, and look straight ahead at me? I'll ask you to close your eyes and hold this position for 10 seconds, and then I'll ask you to open your eyes and see how you're doing."

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll do that. I've been doing it a lot lately, actually, to make sure I don't trip or stumble. I just feel a bit more stable with something to hold onto."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your balance when you're not holding onto anything? Do you feel like you're walking on a tightrope, or is it more of a general sense of instability? Also, I'd like to perform a caloric test to assess your vestibular function. Can you turn your head to the right, keeping your eyes closed, and then suddenly turn it back to the left? And one more thing, have you noticed any numbness or tingling sensations in your face, especially on one side?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I feel like I'm walking on eggshells most of the time. I'm always on the lookout for uneven floors or slippery surfaces, and I have to be extra careful not to trip. It's like my body is constantly trying to compensate for something, but I'm not sure what. As for the caloric test, I'm not sure I can do that. Turning my head is a bit of a challenge for me, to be honest. And as for numbness or tingling, I do have some tingling sensations in my ear when I'm experiencing one of these episodes, but it's not something that happens all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the tingling sensations in your ear? Are they sharp pains or more of a dull ache? And regarding the caloric test, don't worry if you can't do it right now.
